subject: US MARKET WRAP 22 June 2018: Crude jumps on OPEC; Trump threatens EU with higher auto tariffs; Dow snaps losing streak
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat, DXY down, Crude up.
* REAR-VIEW: OPEC agrees to target compliance; Canada CPI and retail sales miss; EZ Flash PMIs strong.
* NEXT WEEK: Turkish General Election, US Durable Goods, US GDP (Final), US Trade Balance, US PCE, RBNZ Rate Decision, EU Summit, Japan Labour Market, German Labour Market, Canadian GDP (monthly).

* TRADE: US President Trump threatened to apply 20% tariffs on all European cars coming into the US if trade barriers and EU tariffs are not 'broken down and removed', he tweeted.  Elsewhere, Russia's economy minister Oreshkin announced Russia will increase tariffs on US autos.

* DATA: Canadian inflation softened in May, missing expectations. The m/m figure came in at 0.1% (consensus 0.3%), headline y/y headline came in at 2.2% (cons 2.3%). The BoC Core measures were also weak, and an average of the three slipped to 1.9% from 2.03%.  Retail Sales also disappointed with the monthly print posting at -1.2%, consensus 0.0%. The negative direction of the latest data has sent the probability of a rate hike in July to around 50%, from the previous 64%. Data remains the main driver for BoC policymakers who have recently expressed less concerns over long-run weaknesses such as housing and consumer debt, Scotiabank notes. They have also noted business investment is picking up, and Scotia still thinks a hike in July is possible.

* SPX +0.2% at 2754, NASDAQ 100 -0.3% at 7197, DJI +0.5% at 24581. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -0.1%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.9%, Energy: +2.2%, Financials: -0.5%, Health Care: -0.4%, Industrials: +0.3%, Materials: +1.4%, Telecoms: +1.2%, Tech: -0.4%, Utilities: +0.7%.

* EQUITY FUTURES: The US equity futures had a relatively quiet day; the Emini grinded higher overnight, but at the Wall St. open it fell ~10points in the first hour, before losses were erased as the day progressed.

* EQUITY SECTORS: The energy sector led the way on Friday trade, tracking higher oil prices after the OPEC meeting (see crude section). Financials underperformed today among the tech sector who were hampered by RHT earnings. 

* EARNINGS: CarMax (KMX) reported earnings which beat on both the top and bottom line, and stated wholesale vehicle unit sales increased by 9.6% in Q1, and its used vehicle sales increased by 1.6% for the same period. The stock outperformed the SPX , nearly raising as much as 15%. The laggard of the SPX was RedHat (RHT), which fell victim to a poor earnings report, where its guidance was lower than Wall St expectations, seeing the stock trade lower by as much as 15%, despite beating its numbers on both top and bottom line. The poor outlook spilt over into some other software names such as Splunk (SPLK), Microsoft (MSFT) and VM Ware (VMW).

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Noteworthy for US auto names (but more so European ones), President Trump threatened a 20% tariff on EU autos imported into the US if trade barriers and tariffs were not lowered or removed. In an immediate reaction auto names spiked lower in both regions, however some of the losses were pared back and GM and FCAU closed higher, but F and HOG remained in the red.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) 1 TICK LOWER AT 119-26+. Treasuries were flat on Friday, and volume was thin, though the complex does close higher for the second straight week, ahead of next week, where the US Treasury will auction more than $200bln of paper. Higher stocks initially had Treasuries on the back foot on Friday, and yields were also dancing to the tune of oil prices. But losses were pared as we headed into the close, with the curve steepening a touch on the day.

* WTI CRUDE FUTURES (Q8) SETTLE $3.04 HIGHER AT $68.58; BRENT CRUDE FUTURES (Q8) SETTLE $2.50 HIGHER AT $75.55/BBL. Crude prices bounced after OPEC agreed to relax supply curbs by less than was guided by the various ‘sources’ reports over the last fortnight. While the cartel did not specify a figure in its communique, ministers said supply would be increased by around 1mln BPD, though netting the impact of current Venezuelan outages, the ‘real’ figure would be between 600-800k BPD (depending on who you ask). The cartel also stressed it was targeting a compliance level of 100% (from 147% at current rates); it said that if a particular member is unable to reach its compliance level, other members would be able to negotiate to fill in any voids, and that would be a process between the individual members. Crude rallied after the announcements filter through into the market, apparently on relief that the relaxation in curbs was not as stark as was guided earlier.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: DXY: The index and broad Usd have been thwarted by several factors at the end of a week that looked very promising at one stage when the DXY notched a new 2018 peak just over 95.500. On Friday the chief negatives came via energy and oil prices in particular that spiked sharply on OPEC’s decision to loosen its output cap via stricter compliance amidst ‘general’ agreement that this equates a nominal rise of 1 mn bpd, or 600-800k in physical terms. Back to the Dollar, and the retreat actually started yesterday on the back of disappointing macros releases, and especially the Philly Fed survey, while strong recoveries in currency counterparts also impacted again. The index is currently retesting 93.500.

* AUD, NZD: The main beneficiaries of the Usd pull-back and short squeeze in crude, with the Aud also unwinding and reversing post-dovish RBA minutes underperformance with the aid of supportive fiscal policy in the form of income tax cuts. Indeed, Aud/Usd has rebounded to just under 0.7450 from sub-0.7350 at one stage, and from a chart perspective it would be constructive to close above 0.7413. Similarly, but not quite as emphatically, the Kiwi is back near 0.6900 from a low of 0.6823, though still circa 50 pips below where it started on Monday. AUDNZD over 1.0750 again has not helped, while some defensive positioning may be weighing ahead of next week’s RBNZ policy meeting.

* EUR, GBP: Upbeat Eurozone preliminary PMIs offset more political jitters (via reports that Germany’s SPD is preparing for snap elections) to keep the single currency on the recovery path from 1.1510 ytd lows vs the Usd, but unable convincingly clear the 21 DMA (1.1671) and layered bids up to 1.1700. Meanwhile, the Pound got its biggest boost alongside some better Brexit news via the passage of EU withdrawal bill amendments through Parliament with more concessions, from an unexpected hawkish shift at the BoE, as Haldane joined the 2 existing rate hike dissenters. Moreover, the minutes were more upbeat on inflation and insistent that negligible Q1 growth was down to bad weather, while the rate at which APF will no longer be reinvested was cut to 1.5% from 2%. Cable duly jumped from circa 1.3100 lows and is now just under 1.3300 having tested resistance and offers just above, with 1.3243 key on a closing basis.

* CAD: The G10 laggard even though oil’s revival provided some comfort for the Loonie, as soft inflation and simply weak retail sales compounded ongoing NAFTA uncertainty/divergence with the US that has highlighted so publicly at the G7 summit. Usd/Cad started the week circa 1.3200 and hit a low just under 1.3160 but catapulted to 1.3380 in wake of the data misses before easing back and perhaps respecting strong chart resistance just shy of 1.3390. However, a bleak BoC outlook next week could see the Loonie suffer anew, and vice-versa of course.

* JPY, CHF: Mixed fortunes for the traditional safe havens, with the Jpy choppy between 109.50-110.75 vs the Greenback and trading on swings in US-China/global trade sentiment as all sides upped the ante on tariffs and sanctions, but have yet to impose stiffer import levies, leaving some time to talk and room for compromise before impending implementation dates. The Franc has gained vs the Dollar to test sub-0.9900 levels, but lost ground vs the Eur to 1.1500+ on latest pledges to keep policy loose and intervene at the mid-year SNB policy review.

* COMING-UP: Sunday: Turkish General Election; Monday: German IFO; Wednesday: BoE Governor Carney speaks, US Durable Goods, Trade Balance; Thursday: RBNZ Rate Decision, German CPI (Prelim), US GDP (Final), EU Summit; Friday: Japan Labour Market, German Labour Market, UK GDP (Final), EZ CPI, US PCE, Canadian GDP (monthly). Click here for full briefing.

subject: FX Weekly Wrap: some surprising results, bad misses and strong performances
content:
DXY

The index and broad Usd have been thwarted by several factors at the end of a week that looked very promising at one stage when the DXY notched a new 2018 peak just over 95.500. On Friday the chief negatives came via energy and oil prices in particular that spiked sharply on OPEC’s decision to loosen its output cap via stricter compliance amidst ‘general’ agreement that this equates a nominal rise of 1 mn bpd, or 600-800k in physical terms. Back to the Dollar, and the retreat actually started yesterday on the back of disappointing macros releases, and especially the Philly Fed survey, while strong recoveries in currency counterparts also impacted again. The index is currently retesting 93.500.

AUD/NZD

The main beneficiaries of the Usd pull-back and short squeeze in crude, with the Aud also unwinding and reversing post-dovish RBA minutes underperformance with the aid of supportive fiscal policy in the form of income tax cuts. Indeed, Aud/Usd has rebounded to just under 0.7450 from sub-0.7350 at one stage, and from a chart perspective it would be constructive to close above 0.7413. Similarly, but not quite as emphatically, the Kiwi is back near 0.6900 from a low of 0.6823, though still circa 50 pips below where it started on Monday. Aud/Nzd over 1.0750 again has not helped, while some defensive positioning may be weighing ahead of next week’s RBNZ policy meeting.

EUR/GBP  

Upbeat Eurozone preliminary PMIs offset more political jitters (via reports that Germany’s SPD is preparing for snap elections) to keep the single currency on the recovery path from 1.1510 ytd lows vs the Usd, but unable convincingly clear the 21 DMA (1.1671) and layered bids up to 1.1700. Meanwhile, the Pound got its biggest boost alongside some better Brexit news via the passage of EU withdrawal bill amendments through Parliament with more concessions, from an unexpected hawkish shift at the BoE, as Haldane joined the 2 existing rate hike dissenters. Moreover, the minutes were more upbeat on inflation and insistent that negligible Q1 growth was down to bad weather, while the rate at which APF will no longer be reinvested was cut to 1.5% from 2%. Cable duly jumped from circa 1.3100 lows and is now just under 1.3300 having tested resistance and offers just above, with 1.3243 key on a closing basis.

CAD    

The G10 laggard even though oil’s revival provided some comfort for the Loonie, as soft inflation and simply weak retail sales compounded ongoing NAFTA uncertainty/divergence with the US that has highlighted so publicly at the G7 summit. Usd/Cad started the week circa 1.3200 and hit a low just under 1.3160, but catapulted to 1.3380 in wake of the data misses before easing back and perhaps respecting strong chart resistance just shy of 1.3390. However, a bleak BoC outlook next week could see the Loonie suffer anew, and vice-versa of course.

JPY/CHF

Mixed fortunes for the traditional safe havens, with the Jpy choppy between 109.50-110.75 vs the Greenback and trading on swings in US-China/global trade sentiment as all sides upped the ante on tariffs and sanctions, but have yet to impose stiffer import levies, leaving some time to talk and room for compromise before impending implementation dates. The Franc has gained vs the Dollar to test sub-0.9900 levels, but lost ground vs the Eur to 1.1500+ on latest pledges to keep policy loose and intervene at the mid-year SNB policy review.

NOK/SEK  

The Nok has sharply outperformed its Scandi peer and the Eur on diverging policy dynamics as the Norges Bank essentially confirmed September as the month to lift rates, while the Sek was hit by political jitters after Sweden’s Democrats called for a post-election EU referendum. Eur/Nok hit fresh ytd lows under 9.4000 on Thursday, but has been caught between hefty option expiry interest today at the 9.4000 and 9.4500 strikes. Conversely, Eur/Sek is back over 10.3000 and the cross close to 1.1000.

  • CarMax (KMX) Q1 EPS USD 1.33 vs. Exp. USD 1.24, revenue USD 4.79bln vs. exp. USD 4.61bln. Total used unit sales increased by 1.6% and wholesale unit sales increased by 9.6% in Q1. (Newswires)
  • RedHat (RHT) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.72 vs Exp. USD 0.69, revenue USD 0.815 vs. Exp. USD 0.807bln. Sees Q2 EPS USD 0.81, vs Exp. USD 0.89, and sees revenue at USD 822mln – USD 830mln, vs Exp. USD 854.95mln. Forecasts, FY19 EPS USD 3.44 - USD 3.48, vs Exp. USD 3.42. The results are weighing on software names, MSFT, VMW, ORCL, SPLK. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant filed inspections in four patents held by Qualcomm (QCOM) over circuit memory, displays, digital assistance devices. (Newswires)
  • Disney (DIS) – The co. is to double its asset sales that yielded USD 1bln in EBITDA to obtain approval for its Twenty-Century Fox (FOXA) offer. (Newswires)

  • HealthEquity (HQY) – The co. named Ted Bloomberg COO. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 22nd June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • OPEC deal nears conclusion as Iran strikes collaborative tone
  • EUR loses PMI steam after Germany’s SPD prepares for elections
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, Canadian CPI & Retail Sales and the OPEC press conference

22nd June 2018

ASIA

Asia stocks were somewhat mixed with the region cautious as trade concerns lingered and following a weak lead from Wall St where all major US indices closed negative and the DJIA declined for an 8th consecutive day to post its longest losing streak in over a year. As such, Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) saw early underperformance amid recent JPY strength, while ASX 200 (-0.2%) bucked the trend for most the session amid strength in financials led by ANZ Bank which announced to double its share repurchase. Elsewhere, trade concerns continued to cloud over the Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) from the open, although stocks then recovered as participants also digested another net weekly liquidity injection from the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with prices sitting near 2-week highs, while the latest CPI data from Japan was largely ignored despite the headline being a tad firmer than expected as inflation remained far from the 2% price goal. In addition, today’s BoJ Rinban announcement also failed to spur demand as the central bank maintained all purchase amounts.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos, for a net weekly injection of CNY 140bln vs. last week's CNY 240bln net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4804 (Prev. 6.4706)

Some US administration officials are reportedly pushing for resuming talks with China due to a split opinion among the Trump trade team in which 'high level' talks would take place before July 6th, according to three people familiar with the matter. However, the report also noted chances of near term negotiations are slim and that Trump shows no sign of backing down. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (May) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (May) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (May) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Norges Bank's Olsen says the NOK is still 'quite weak' and signalling an interest rate move is 'never a promise'. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

German SPD's Klingbeil is said to have held election preparation meetings. (Newswires)

Italy's Head of the Lower House Budget panel says a Euro exit is not in the government programme but regaining monetary sovereignty would aid Italy. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Jun) 55.0 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.5)

EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Jun) 55.0 vs. Exp. 53.7 (Prev. 53.8)

EU Markit Composite Flash PMI (Jun) 54.8 vs. Exp. 53.9 (Prev. 54.1)

EQUITIES

European bourses are largely higher (Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%) with bank stocks leading the gains on Friday, as fears over Italian Euroscepticism ease, as Borghi reiterates there is no intention to leave the Euro Zone. The energy sector was dragging on equities as OPEC accord tensions pressured the sector but bounced on a deal nearing closure.

The SMI is currently the outperforming bourse whilst the DAX underperforms as trade concerns linger over German auto names and pressure on the index.

French company specific news dominates newswires, with the French Government saying they have no intention of breaking up EDF (flat) into a nuclear and non-nuclear unit, as well as Airbus (+1.5%) on a positive note being circulated from JP Morgan.

FX

EUR - The single currency has continued its firm rebound from post-Fed and especially ECB policy meeting lows, with upbeat preliminary PMIs for June providing additional momentum to extend recovery gains beyond 1.1600 vs the Usd and briefly challenging the 21 DMA around 1.1670. However, offers layered between there and 1.1700 are capping further upside for now, and reports that Germany’s SPD are preparing for an election also undermined the single currency.

AUD/NZD - The major beneficiaries a pre-OPEC squeeze in oil prices and broad Greenback retracement in wake of yesterday’s disappointing US data (Philly Fed survey in particular), as the former regains 0.7400 and looks to close above a chart pivot circa 0.7413, while the latter is hovering around 0.6900.

GBP - Building on post-BoE gains with Cable testing 1.3300 for a near 2 big figure bounce from worst levels in the run up to Thursday’s MPC policy revelations, but also meeting some technical resistance ahead of its 21 DMA (1.3310).

CHF/JPY - The renowned safe-havens remain rather divergent vs the Usd, with the Franc firmer either side of 0.9900, but Jpy back below 110.00 as chart support at the 30 DMA (109.99) was only breached fleetingly.

CAD - Consolidating above 1.3300 against its US counterpart and eyeing crude ahead of OPEC like the antipodean dollars and other commodity currencies, but also looking towards Canadian CPI and retail sales data for independent impetus ahead of next week’s BoC outlook report.

DXY - Finding some support around 94.500, but off fresh ytd peaks some 100 ticks higher on the aforementioned worse-than-forecast US releases and decent recoveries in rival trading partners.

FIXED INCOME

UK debt and STIR contracts are back-pedalling having recovered some lost ground in wake of Thursday’s hawkish BoE twist, but not solely on the tighter vote split or latest MPC minutes as Bunds have also recoiled further from yesterday’s peaks amidst broadly upbeat Eurozone PMIs – to test near term chart support at 161.80 (-35 ticks on the day), which equates to a 50% retracement of Thursday’s move. Back to Liffe, the 10 year bond has been down to 122.63 vs the previous 123.03 close after an initial print of 122.99 that also marks the high so far, while the 3 month strip hit lows as much as 4 ticks under parity. Elsewhere, US Treasuries remain close to overnight session lows with the curve mildly steeper ahead of the flash PMIs.

COMMODITIES

Oil trades higher as OPEC near an agreement on an output increase. Initially sources had suggested that ‘building [a] consensus [would] be a big challenge’ and ‘not all OPEC members [were] likely to accept the Ministerial Committee's proposal for an oil output increase of around 1mln BPD’.

Whilst source reports had also suggested that Iran were doubting a consensus could be reached a more collaborative tone was struck after last minute talks and negotiations, with Iran stating that the meeting with the Saudi Oil Minister was positive. Following this multiple oil ministers confirmed that a compromise deal including a higher Iran quota may be part of the agreement and the 1mln BPD increase was an overestimation. The real effect is to be 700k BPD as according to the Nigerian Energy Minsiter.

Libyan oil ports had exacerbated the rise in oil, with a further storage tank catching fire due to domestic conflicts. However, Libya’s NOC has confirmed Ras Lanuf and Es Sider are under the control of Libya’s National Army, with fires now all extinguished.

Gold is up slightly heading in to the weeks end as the USD edges off of 11 month highs. Steel is set for the worst week in two months as the metal is eyeing losses once again on Friday. Copper is also set to fall on Friday as worries loom about falling Chinese demand due to trade concerns.

subject: BofAML Weekly Flows report: Quantitative Tightening flows
content:
• Equities: large outflows $12.9bn ($0.4bn ETF outflows, $12.6bn mutual fund outflows)
  • Bonds: biggest outflows in 18 weeks ($5.9bn)
  • Precious metals: biggest outflows since Dec'16 ($0.8bn)

Fixed Income Flows

  • Biggest IG bond fund outflows since Dec'16 ($2.6bn)
  • HY bond outflows 7th consecutive week ($1.4bn)
  • 9th straight week of EM debt outflows ($1.7bn)
  • 7th straight week of muni fund inflows ($0.4bn)
  • Modest Govt/Tsy outflows ($0.6bn)
  • Small TIPS outflows ($0.1bn)
  • Bank loan fund inflows 17 consecutive weeks ($0.4bn)

Equity Flows:

  • US: inflows 7th straight weeks ($5.1bn)
  • Japan: notable outflows ($1.8bn)
  • Europe: massive outflows continue ($2.7bn)
  • EM: biggest outflows since Nov'16 ($5.1bn)
  • By style: inflows US growth ($7.0bn), US large cap ($4.8bn), US small cap ($1.3n), US value ($14mn)
  • By sector: inflows consumer ($0.7bn), energy ($0.5bn), utilities ($0.4bn), materials ($0.3bn), tech ($0.3bn); outflows healthcare ($0.2bn), real estate ($0.4bn), financials ($1.4bn)

Talking Points

  • 2018 YTD global returns: commodities 5.3%, US dollar 3.3%, equities 1.2%, cash 0.7%, govt bonds -1.0%, HY bonds -1.1%, IG bonds -3.5%.
  • Risk-off flows: $12.9bn out of equities, $5.9bn out of bonds, $0.8bn out of gold.
  • US decoupling accelerates: $5.1bn inflows to US stocks, outflows all other regions...$5.1bn out of EM (largest since Nov'16), $2.7bn out of Europe and $38.6bn over the past 15 weeks (as US-German bond yield spread widest since fall of Berlin Wall), $1.9bn out of Japan.
  • Tech an Oasis: flows to tech thus far immune to summer macro & market woes; tech funds on course for record annualized inflow of $37bn, more inflows this week.
  • An exodus from Financials: biggest redemptions from financials ($1.4bn) since Sept'16.
  • Investment Grade downgraded: biggest week of IG outflows ($2.6bn) since Dec'16; further outflows from HY & EM debt.
  • 2018 roadmap: asset prices broadly following our peak Profits, peak Policy script YTD; Quantitative Tightening (not tax cuts, trade wars...) is the driver…hence underperformance of QE winners (EM debt, HY, IG), outperformance of QE losers (volatility, cash, commodities, US$); tech stocks are the anomaly, but largely vulnerable to investor deleveraging
  • Bull & Bear hits 2-year low: BofAML Bull & Bear indicator @ 2.9, moving toward summer "buy signal"; triggers likely to be further outflows from risk assets (e.g. $35bn equities, $5bn HY redemptions in coming weeks), plus clear break in SPX below important 2650 level, weak June payroll that could take a Fed hike or two off the table; we remain bearish until then.

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session - 22nd June 2018
content:
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: EUR bid post PMIs, crude bid on rising OPEC pact hopes

EQUITIES

European bourses are largely higher (Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%) with bank stocks leading the gains on Friday, as fears over Italian Euroscepticism ease, as Borghi reiterates there is no intention to leave the Euro Zone. The energy sector was dragging on equities as OPEC accord tensions pressured the sector but bounced on a deal nearing closure.

The SMI is currently the outperforming bourse whilst the DAX underperforms as trade concerns linger over German auto names and pressure on the index.

French company specific news dominates newswires, with the French Government saying they have no intention of breaking up EDF (flat) into a nuclear and non-nuclear unit, as well as Airbus (+1.5%) warning of a contingency plan to leave the UK should a no-deal Brexit happen, with this possibly leading to thousands of lost jobs.

FX

EUR - The single currency has continued its firm rebound from post-Fed and especially ECB policy meeting lows, with upbeat preliminary PMIs for June providing additional momentum to extend recovery gains beyond 1.1600 vs the Usd and briefly challenging the 21 DMA around 1.1670. However, offers layered between there and 1.1700 are capping further upside for now.

AUD/NZD - The major beneficiaries a pre-OPEC squeeze in oil prices and broad Greenback retracement in wake of yesterday’s disappointing US data (Philly Fed survey in particular), as the former regains 0.7400 and looks to close above a chart pivot circa 0.7413, while the latter is hovering around 0.6900.

GBP - Building on post-BoE gains with Cable testing 1.3300 for a near 2 big figure bounce from worst levels in the run up to Thursday’s MPC policy revelations, but also meeting some technical resistance ahead of its 21 DMA (1.3310).

CHF/JPY - The renowned safe-havens remain rather divergent vs the Usd, with the Franc firmer either side of 0.9900, but Jpy back below 110.00 as chart support at the 30 DMA (109.99) was only breached fleetingly.

CAD - Consolidating above 1.3300 against its US counterpart and eyeing crude ahead of OPEC like the antipodean dollars and other commodity currencies, but also looking towards Canadian CPI and retail sales data for independent impetus ahead of next week’s BoC outlook report.

DXY - Finding some support around 94.500, but off fresh ytd peaks some 100 ticks higher on the aforementioned worse-than-forecast US releases and decent recoveries in rival trading partners.

FIXED INCOME

UK debt and STIR contracts are back-pedalling having recovered some lost ground in wake of Thursday’s hawkish BoE twist, but not solely on the tighter vote split or latest MPC minutes as Bunds have also recoiled further from yesterday’s peaks amidst broadly upbeat Eurozone PMIs – to test near term chart support at 161.80 (-35 ticks on the day), which equates to a 50% retracement of Thursday’s move. Back to Liffe, the 10 year bond has been down to 122.63 vs the previous 123.03 close after an initial print of 122.99 that also marks the high so far, while the 3 month strip hit lows as much as 4 ticks under parity. Elsewhere, US Treasuries remain close to overnight session lows with the curve mildly steeper ahead of the flash PMIs.

COMMODITIES

Oil is paring back some of the losses seen in Thursday’s trade and is up as OPEC were struggling to reach an accord on the oil output deal, with consistent dissent coming from the Iranian/Iraqi delegates. Reports suggestted that ‘building [a] consensus will be a big challenge’ and ‘not all OPEC members are likely to accept the Ministerial Committee's proposal for an oil output increase of around 1mln BPD’. Iran Oil Minister also said he doubts OPEC can reach consensus on supply cut deal, after leaving the monitoring committee meeting abruptly. Later in the day however, a deal seemed to be nearing, with Iran striking a more collaborative tone after last minute talks and negotiations.

Libyan oil ports have exacerbated the rise in oil, with a further storage tank catching fire due to domestic conflicts.

Gold is up slightly heading in to the weeks end as the USD edges off of 11 month highs. Steel is set for the worst week in two months as the metal is eyeing losses once again on Friday. Copper is also set to fall on Friday as worries loom about falling Chinese demand due to trade concerns.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 22nd June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks mixed; DJIA closed lower for 8th consecutive trading session
  • WTI and Brent crude higher amid uncertainty ahead of today’s OPEC meeting
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone PMIs, Canadian CPI, and the OPEC meeting

ASIA

Asia stocks were somewhat mixed with the region cautious as trade concerns lingered and following a weak lead from Wall St where all major US indices closed negative and the DJIA declined for an 8th consecutive day to post its longest losing streak in over a year. As such, Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) saw early underperformance amid recent JPY strength, while ASX 200 (-0.2%) bucked the trend for most the session amid strength in financials led by ANZ Bank which announced to double its share repurchase. Elsewhere, trade concerns continued to cloud over the Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) from the open, although stocks then recovered as participants also digested another net weekly liquidity injection from the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively unchanged with prices sitting near 2-week highs, while the latest CPI data from Japan was largely ignored despite the headline being a tad firmer than expected as inflation remained far from the 2% price goal. In addition, today’s BoJ Rinban announcement also failed to spur demand as the central bank maintained all purchase amounts.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos, for a net weekly injection of CNY 140bln vs. last week's CNY 240bln net injection. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4804 (Prev. 6.4706)

Some US administration officials are reportedly pushing for resuming talks with China due to a split opinion among the Trump trade team in which 'high level' talks would take place before July 6th, according to three people familiar with the matter. However, the report also noted chances of near term negotiations are slim and that Trump shows no sign of backing down. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (May) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)
Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (May) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)
Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (May) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%)

UK/EU

Germany BDI industry body said UK is on course for a disorderly exit from the EU and that UK must accept staying in customs union and EU market are the only solutions to the Irish border issue. (Newswires)

Greece’s creditors agreed on a debt relief package which includes a 10yr EFSF loan extension, while Greece is to receive EUR 15bln as a final bailout disbursement. Furthermore, Eurogroup President Centeno said there will be no follow up programme with Greece after exit of the current bailout and that they also agreed to a 10yr deferral on interest and amortisation, while he added this will allow Greece to issue bonds across the curve. (Newswires)

Italy’s EU affairs minister Savona said he has always maintained that Italy needs the Euro and single market. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets were quiet during Asia trade, although the greenback found some mild reprieve from the prior day’s weakness in which the DXY attempted to recover lost ground below the 95.00 level. Elsewhere, EUR/USD briefly pulled back to test 1.1600 to the downside and GBP/USD maintained the momentum from the prior day’s more-hawkish-split-surprise at the BoE, while commodity-linked currencies coat-tailed on overnight gains in oil prices.

COMMODITIES

Oil prices outperformed in commodities overnight in which WTI reclaimed the USD 66/bbl level ahead of today’s OPEC meeting. Furthermore, the upside coincided with the reopen of Brent futures which were underpinned following reports that the OPEC+ committee were backing a 1mln bpd increase which they stressed was nominal and could effectively be only 600k bpd once distributed due to current over compliance. Elsewhere, the metals complex was less eventful with gold and copper prices sideways amid cautious risk tone and attempts by the greenback to nurse losses.    

OPEC+ committee is said to support 1mln bpd output increase "on paper". Iraq Oil Minister Al-Luaibi said OPEC+ Committee has reached a preliminary decision and that a majority backed the output increase which would be gradual and nominal. Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih also commented that the output increase proposal is nominal which means it would be actually smaller once distributed, while a delegate suggested the OPEC+ proposal would result to a real increase of 600K bpd. Furthermore, Iraq and Oman Oil Ministers reportedly think Iran can agree on the output increase. (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister said he doubts OPEC can reach consensus on supply cut deal, after leaving the monitoring committee meeting abruptly. (Platts)

A third oil storage tank at Ras Lanuf refinery was set on fire at the clashes at the Libyan oil port. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITCAL

US President Trump said North Korea is blowing up its test sites, while a spokesperson stated that US Secretary of State Pompeo will meet North Korean officials 'at the earliest possible date' to outline the outcomes of the Trump-Kim summit. (Newswires)

US

Treasuries were higher on Thursday, following the move lower in equities, as risk sentiment deteriorated throughout the session ahead of OPEC+ meeting tomorrow and as trade war fear returns in the market and amid disappointing Philly Fed data. Yields were lower by c.3bps across the curve, 2s5s and 2s20 narrowed by c.2bps. 2s30s narrowed by c.1bps. The US Treasury sold $5bln in 30yr TIPS stopping through by 0.6bps at a high yield of 0.934%. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.62x. Dealers were awarded the smallest portion of the latest 30yr TIPS supply at 14.6% while indirects/directs took a share well above average, at 80.8% and 4.6% respectively. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) finished 8 ticks higher at 119-27+.

US President Trump noted there may be a little pain on Canada but added that it will work out. (Newswires)

Fed annual stress test results showed all 35 largest US banks exceed minimum capital requirements. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade lower as trade concerns lingered and amid spillover selling from US where the DJIA notched its longest losing streak in over a year
content:
Asia stocks are mostly lower as trade concerns lingered and following a weak lead from Wall St where all majors closed negative and the DJIA declined for an 8th consecutive day to post its longest losing streak in over a year. As such, Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) saw early underperformance amid recent JPY strength while trade concerns continue to cloud over the Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) but with losses in the latter contained amid a liquidity injection from the PBoC. Conversely, ASX 200 (Unch) bucked the trend for most the session and remains near decade highs with its largest sector financials front-running the outperformance as ANZ Bank gains following the announcement to double its share repurchase.

FX markets are quiet so far during Asia trade, although the greenback found some mild reprieve from the prior day’s weakness with the DXY attempting to recover lost ground below the 95.00 level. Elsewhere, EUR/USD has slightly pulled back to test 1.1600 to the downside and GBP/USD maintains the momentum from the prior day’s more hawkish-split-surprise at the BoE, while commodity-linked currencies coat-tail on overnight gains in oil prices.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively unchanged with prices sitting near 2-week highs, while the latest CPI data from Japan was largely ignored despite the headline being a tad firmer than expected as inflation remains far from the 2% price goal. In addition, today’s BoJ Rinban announcement also failed to spur demand as the central bank maintained its purchase amounts.
